terms.definition: Document Management System - a software platform that stores, organizes, and manages digital documents in a centralized location
Role-Based Access Control - a security method that restricts system access based on user roles and permissions within an organization
A centralized repository of information and documentation that provides self-service answers to common questions and problems
The practice of maintaining multiple versions of documents to track changes and provide access to historical content
A support model where customers can find answers and solve problems independently using documentation and resources without contacting support staff
Content Management System - software that allows users to create, edit, and publish digital content without technical expertise
JavaScript Object Notation - a lightweight, text-based data format used for storing and exchanging information between systems
Governance Risk and Compliance - policies and procedures that manage organizational risks and ensure adherence to regulations
A lightweight markup language that uses plain text formatting to create structured documents that can be converted to HTML
Open Document Format - an open standard file format for office documents that ensures compatibility across different software applications
Cascading Style Sheets - a language used to describe the visual presentation and formatting of web pages and documents
When a customer base is split across multiple versions of the same software or service, creating documentation challenges
The practice of controlling and coordinating all documentation processes from a single location or system
HyperText Markup Language - the standard language used to create and structure content on web pages
Electronic documents and content stored in digital formats that can be accessed, shared, and managed through computer systems
